facts.text: Lakshminarayana Iyer died on 13th December, 1924

anchor.surface_text: One Lakshminarayana Iyer, a Hindu Brahmin, who owned companysiderable properties in the Tirunelveli district, died on 13th December, 1924, leaving him surviving a widow Ranganayaki, and a married daughter Ramalakshmi.

facts.text: Lakshminarayana Iyer executed a will on 16th November, 1924

anchor.surface_text: They were all alive in December, 1924, when Lakshminarayana died, Before his death he executed a will on 16th November, 1924, the companystruction of which is in companytroversy in this appeal.

facts.text: Lakshminarayana Iyer left surviving a widow Ranganayaki and a married daughter Ramalakshmi

anchor.surface_text: leaving him surviving a widow Ranganayaki, and a married daughter Ramalakshmi. Ramalakshmi had married the plaintiff and had a number of children from him.

facts.text: Ramalakshmi had a number of children from the plaintiff, all alive in December 1924

anchor.surface_text: Ramalakshmi had married the plaintiff and had a number of children from him. They were all alive in December, 1924, when Lakshminarayana died, Before his death he executed a will

facts.text: By the will, Ranganayaki Amminal to enjoy entire properties till her lifetime

anchor.surface_text: By this will he gave the following directions -- After my lifetime, you, the aforesaid Ranganayaki Amminal, my wife, shall till your lifetime, enjoy the aforesaid entire properties, the outstandings due to me, the debts payable by me, and the chit amounts payable by me.

facts.text: By the will, after Ranganayaki's lifetime, Ramalakshmi Ammal and her heirs to enjoy properties with absolute rights and powers of alienation

anchor.surface_text: After your lifetime Ramalakshmi Ammal, our daughter and wife of Rama Ayyar Avergal of Melagaram village, and her heirs shall enjoy them with absolute rights and powers of alienation such as gift, exchange, and sale from son to grandson and so on for generations.

facts.text: Will directed Ranganayaki to pay maintenance to Chinnanmal alias Lakshmi Ammal and obtain release deed

anchor.surface_text: As regards the payment of maintenance to be made to Chinnanmal alias Lakshmi Ammal, wife of my late son Hariharamayyan, my wife Ranganayaki Ammal shall pay the same as she pleases, and obtain a release deed.

facts.text: Ranganayaki entered into possession of the properties on the death of her husband

anchor.surface_text: Ranganayaki entered into possession of the properties on the death of her husband.

facts.text: On 21st February, 1928, Ranganayaki settled maintenance claim of Lakshmi Ammal by paying Rs. 3,350 cash and agreement for Rs. 240 per annum

anchor.surface_text: On 21st February, 1928, she settled the maintenance claim of Lakshmi Ammal and obtained a deed of release from her by paying her a sum of Rs. 3,350 in cash and by executing in her favour an agreement stipulating to pay her a sum of Rs. 240 per annum.

facts.text: Ramalakshmi died on 25th April, 1938 during lifetime of the widow, none of her children survived her

anchor.surface_text: Ramalakshmi died on 25th April, 1938 during the lifetime of the widow. None of her children survived her.

facts.text: Plaintiff is husband and sole heir of Ramalakshmi

anchor.surface_text: the suit out of which this appeal arises was instituted by the plaintiff, the husband and the sole heir of Ramalakshmi

facts.text: On 24th July, 1945, widow sold one item of property to 2nd defendant for Rs. 500

anchor.surface_text: On the 24th July, 1945, the widow describing herself as an absolute owner of the properties of her husband sold one of the items of the property to the 2nd defendant for Rs. 500.

facts.text: Suit instituted on 18th September, 1945 by plaintiff for declaration that sale not binding beyond widow's lifetime

anchor.surface_text: On the 18th September, 1945, the suit out of which this appeal arises was instituted by the plaintiff... for a declaration that the said sale would number be binding on him beyond the lifetime of the widow.

facts.text: Ad interim injunction issued on 19th September, 1945 restraining widow from alienating properties

anchor.surface_text: On the 19th September, 1945, an ad interim injunction was issued by the High Court restraining the widow from alienating the properties in her possession and forming part of her husbands estate,

facts.text: Despite injunction, on 27th September, 1945, widow executed two deeds of settlement in favour of other defendants

anchor.surface_text: In spite of this injunction, on the 27th September, 1945, she executed two deeds of settlement in favour of the other defendants companyprising a number of properties.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge of Tinnevelly gave judgment on 13th August, 1946 in Original Suit No. 50 of 1945

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated the 27th February, 1950, of the High Court... arising, out of judgment and decree dated the 13th August, 1946, of the Court of the Subordinate Judge of Tinnevelly in Original Suit No. 50 of 1945.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge held widow took limited life interest, not absolute or widow's estate; daughter got vested interest; plaintiff succeeded; alienations not beyond lifetime

anchor.surface_text: The subordinate judge held that the widow took under the will a limited life, interest, and number an absolute estate or even a widows estate under Hindu law, and that the daughter got thereunder a vested interest in the properties to which the plaintiff succeeded on her death.

facts.text: High Court of Madras judgment dated 27th February, 1950 in Appeal No. 635 of 1946 affirmed trial court

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated the 27th February, 1950, of the High Court of Judicature at Madras  Rao and Ayyar JJ.  in Appeal No. 635 of 1946

facts.text: Widow died on 14th February, 1948 during pendency of appeal to High Court

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of the appeal the widow died on 14th February, 1948.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal admitted on 27th November, 1951

anchor.surface_text: Leave to appeal to the Supreme Court was granted and the appeal was admitted on the 27th November, 1951.

facts.text: Defendants pleaded plaintiff had no title to sue, widow had absolute or widow's estate, daughter's interest contingent

anchor.surface_text: The defendants pleaded that the plaintiff had numbertitle to maintain the suit, that the widow was entitled under the will to an absolute estate or at least to an estate analogous to and number less than a widows estate, that the estate given to Ramalakshmi under the will was but a companytingent one

facts.text: Supreme Court held widow had limited life estate, not Hindu widow's estate; daughter had vested interest

anchor.surface_text: We therefore hold that the estate companyferred on Ranganayaki Ammal was more like the limited estate in the English sense of the term than like a full Hindu widows estate in spite of the directions above- mentioned.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 95 of 1952 before Supreme Court

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 95 of 1952.

facts.text: Ranganayaki alienated one property in 1937 to raise Rs. 1,000 to buy land, substituting properties

anchor.surface_text: It is number shown that she alienated a single item of immovable property till the year 1945, a period of over 21 years after the death of her husband, excepting one, which she alienated in the year 1937 to raise a sum of Rs. 1,000 in order to buy some land.

facts.text: Properties were considerable in extent and fetched sufficient income
